tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
Possible meanings are 1) "the one who keeps me safe" or 2) "the one who gives me strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: who trains my hands for war and my fingers for battle
tn.text: The words "hands" and "fingers" are synecdoches for "me." If "war" and "battle" are the same word in your language, you can translate this as one line. AT: "who trains me for war and trains me for battle" or "who trains me for war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"the one who shows me covenant faithfulness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The psalmist uses many metaphors to emphasize that Yahweh will protect him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a fortress that protects him from attack. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a shield that protects a soldier. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:002|18:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the one in whom I take refuge
tn.text: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "the one to whom I go so he will protect me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the one who subdues nations under me
tn.text: "the one who enables me to defeat other nations"

tn.ref: Yahweh, what is man that you take notice of him or the son of man that you think about him?
tn.text: These questions can be translated as statements. AT: "Man is so small compared to everything else you have made that I am surprised that you take notice of man and that you think about the son of man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
two words for human beings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: like a breath ... like a passing shadow
tn.text: The writer compares humans to these thing to emphasize how short their lives are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Cause ... come down ... touch ... make ... Send ... scatter ... shoot ... drive
tn.text: These should probably be translated as requests, not commands, since the psalmist considers God greater than him.
Possible meanings are 1) tear the sky open or 2) bend the heavens like a tree branch bends when someone walks on it or as one bends a bow before shooting arrows.
"so they do not know what to think or what to do"

tn.ref: Reach out your hand from above; rescue me out of many waters
tn.text: David speaks as if God were on land above a flood and had physical hands with which he could pull David out of a flood. The flood is a metaphor for the troubles caused by the "foreigners." AT: "You who are able to act, help me overcome my troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "hand" refers to power. AT: "from the power of foreigners" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"They speak lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) David speaks of the custom of raising the right hand to swear that what one is about to say in court is true, "they lie even when they swear to tell the truth," or 2) the "right hand" is a metaphor for power, "everything they have gotten, they have gotten by telling lies." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) "a song no one has ever sung before" or 2) "a song I have never sung before."

tn.ref: you, who give ... kings, who rescued
tn.text: "you. It is you who give ... kings. It is you who rescued"
David speaks of himself as if he were someone else. "me, David, your servant"
David speaks of evil people as if they were the swords they use as weapons. AT: "from evil people who were trying to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Please rescue me and free me"
Here "hand" refers to power. Translate these words as you translated them in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:144:007|144:7-8]]. AT: "from the power of foreigners" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"They speak lies." Translate these words as you translated them in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:144:007|144:7-8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) David speaks of the custom of raising the right hand to swear that what one is about to say in court is true, "they lie even when they swear to tell the truth," or 2) the "right hand" is a metaphor for power, "everything they have gotten, they have gotten by telling lies."Translate these words as you translated them in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:144:007|144:7-8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: like plants who grow to full size
tn.text: healthy and strong
the time when people develop

tn.ref: our daughters like carved corner pillars
tn.text: "may our daughters be like carved corner pillars"
"beautiful posts that hold up the corners of a large house"

tn.ref: pillars, shapely like those of a palace
tn.text: "pillars that are carved to make a palace beautiful"

tn.ref: thousands and ten thousands in our fields
tn.text: "thousands—even tens of thousands!—and fill up our fields" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: No one will break through our walls
tn.text: "No one will be able to invade our city"
"no one crying in pain" or "no one begging for food" or "no one calling out for justice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
